DOC.HEADLINE: Corporate bankruptcies up 2.5 percent on month in Japan

TEXT.P: Corporate bankruptcies up 2.5 percent on month in Japan

TOKYO, March 8 (Xinhua) -- The number of corporate bankruptcies in Japan increased by 2.5 percent in February compared to the previous month, according to a report released by the Tokyo Shoko Research on Monday.

Compared to the previous year, however, bankruptcies were down 17.2 percent, marking the seventh consecutive month of improving conditions as the nation looks to recover from dour economic conditions triggered by a credit crisis that started in the second half of 2008.

The companies that went bankrupt last month incurred debts of 439 trillion yen (4.85 billion dollars), significantly lower than the previous month, when Japan Airlines (JAL) went into administration. The amount of debt incurred by companies going bankrupt was also 64.2 percent, smaller than that for the same month in 2009.

Sectors badly hit in February included building, service and communications. In February, Japanese wireless carrier Willcom Inc. declared bankruptcy with debts of 206 billion yen (2.3 billion dollars).
In recent months the government and Bank of Japan (BOJ) have put in place a series of measures in an attempt to stimulate growth and household spending, with varying success.

Statistics released earlier on Monday showed the amount of loans taken out from Japanese institutions was down 1.5 percent from a year earlier, indicating that despite government measures, businesses are still over capacity and remain cautious about future investment.
